abstract.p: Capsule reviews of six restaurants in Manhattan's West 40's (M)

block.p: CHURRASCARIA PLATAFORMA [Rating: two stars] (212) 245-0505; 316 West 49th Street; $$; smoking at the bar; all major credit cards.

This all-you-can-eat Brazilian restaurant is distinguished from the others by the high quality of food and the charming attitude of the waiters. The salad bar is extraordinary, a long, two-sided affair anchored at the corners by four hot casseroles. The rodizio starts when a waiter appears with plates of fried potatoes, fried yucca and little squares of fried polenta, a bit of rice, some farofa and a dish of vinaigrette. Next, you will be enticed with at least 10 cuts of meat, many of them beef: sirloin, baby beef, top round, skirt steak, brisket, short ribs and roast beef. Salmon also is served, along with a caper sauce. Just when you've finally cried uncle, the dessert tray arrives with such items as chocolate mousse and queijo, a bright yellow dessert rich with egg yolks and coconut. (Review: 4/4/97)

FIREBIRD [Rating: two stars] (212) 586-0244; 365 West 46th Street; $$$; smoking area at the bar; all major credit cards.

Two brownstones have been combined to recreate a pre-revolutionary Russian mansion. This restaurant deserves an award for set decoration. Current first courses include Maine peekytoe crab and jasmine rice croquettes, with purslane and mustard sauce; crisp seared sweetbreads in Madeira sauce and potato blini with marinated herring. Main courses include Arctic char and Maine sea scallops, with herb-infused tomato with basil walnut pesto; grilled sturgeon, served with sorrel-potato puree, braised carrot and chanterelle mushrooms and horseradish sauce; and mushroom-crusted halibut, with candied onion, tomato and sauce of fresh peas. The caviar are all served with sour cream and blini or toast. (Review: 2/7/97)
IPANEMA + (212) 730-5848; 13 West 46th Street, between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas; $$; smoking at the bar; all major credit cards.

This relaxed, gracious Brazilian restaurant offers big portions of solid fare. Current appetizers include codfish patties; crepes filled with seafood; shrimps in garlic sauce, and fried Portuguese sausage. Entrees include a rich black bean stew with an assortment of smoked meats; grilled marinated shell steak with garlic sauce; chunks of loin of pork and clams in a special herb sauce; grilled boneless chicken topped with cheese; and a medley of lobster, shrimps, clams and mussels in a Bahia sauce or green sauce. ($25 and Under: 10/29/93; New York Today: April 1998)
LATTANZI RISTORANTE +++ (212) 315-0980; 361 West 46th Street, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues; $$; no smoking; American Express only.

Lattanzi is small and dim with an old-fashioned look. At night the Jewish-Italian menu is unusual and appealing. Starters include ceci beans cooked in meat broth, with rosemary and extra virgin olive oil; and homemade mozzarella and fresh tomato. Main dishes include risotto with either porcini mushrooms, barolo sauce, seafood or vegetables; fried baby squid and shrimp; chicken with peppers, onion, oregano and a marinara sauce; veal scaloppine with marsala wine and mushrooms; and homemade noodles filled with veal, chicken and tomato sauce. (New York Today: April 1998)
MARITIME [Rating: one star] (212) 354-1717; 1251 Avenue of the Americas, at West 49th Street; $$$; smoking at the bar; all major credit cards.

This American seafood brasserie has international leanings. The dark mahogany floors have a muted luster, like the deck of a Vanderbilt yacht. Appetizers include curry fried oysters with cucumber-mint raita; Maritime lobster and corn chowder; and creamy lump crab meat and potato latkes with mango and baby greens. Entrees include salmon satay with shrimp fried rice and peanut sauce; grilled swordfish with papaya summer roll and fermented black bean-scallion sauce; pan-seared scallops with homemade pumpkin ravioli, wilted chard and porcini-truffle sauce; and pomegranate-glazed chicken with grilled pineapple and sweet potato-coconut mash. (Review: 12/1/99)
PALLADIN [Rating: two stars] (212) 320-2929; 224 West 49th Street, at Broadway; $$$; smoking at the bar; all major credit cards.

Palladin is a techno-bistro with a lot of sass and style, housed in the Time Hotel in the theater district. Jean-Louis Palladin, the chef who ran the swank Jean Louis in Washington, is a feisty chef with plenty of ideas. Salads and appetizers include the ahi and hamachi carpaccio with a salad of microgreens; Florida conch, served with marinated green mango and red ginger coulis; and endive salad and diver scallops with young carrots and cumin. Main dishes include the herb-wrapped roasted monkfish; roasted black sea bass, with celery, potatoes, pancetta, garlic and young carrots; roasted pastrami squab with sweet and sour cabbage and a pastrami spice sauce; foie gras and duck pot au feu; and polenta-crusted skate wing, served with sweetbread ravigote. (Review: 6/23/99)
